## Brandon Sanderson's Influence

Martin and Brandon Sanderson have become masters in their own right, crafting intricate worlds for A Song of Ice and Fire and the Mistborn series, respectively.(no content)Following in Tolkien's footsteps, modern fantasy authors now consider world-building an essential part of the craft.

## Specific Elements Authors Adopted from Tolkien

### World-Building and Depth
Tolkien's fans often praise his attention to detail, particularly in his extensive world-building. Rooted in his love for language, Tolkien designed every aspect of Middle-earth, from its creation story to its complex linguistic landscape. As a philologist, he even went as far as to create languages for the various inhabitants of his universe, adding unparalleled depth and complexity to his characters.

### Fantasy Races and Archetypes
Tolkien's depiction of races such as elves, dwarves, and orcs solidified their presence in the genre. Many modern fantasy authors adopt or subvert these archetypes, which have become ingrained in our collective cultural imagination.

### Reaction and Innovation
It's not just the tropes and archetypes that writers take from Tolkien; many authors also find inspiration in challenging his conventions. By playing with or deconstructing the expectations established by Tolkien's works, writers can keep the genre fresh and relevant.

## Tolkien's Revolutionary Impact

When J.R.R. Tolkien published The Hobbit in 1937, he could not have known that the book would change the landscape of fantasy literature forever. Tolkien's meticulously crafted Middle-earth proved to be fertile ground for an entire subgenre of high fantasy, inspiring countless authors to create their own epics.(no content)Upon his death, he left a great legacy that shaped the modern fantasy genre, influencing writers both contemporaries and future. Due to this great influence, Tolkien is often referred to as the father of modern fantasy.

The influence extends beyond just these three authors to countless others in the fantasy genre, establishing elements like detailed secondary worlds, complex linguistic systems, archetypal fantasy races, and the quest narrative structure that continue to define fantasy literature today.
